head.title: An American Town Meeting: The Issue Is Race; The Cubans

hedline.hl1: An American Town Meeting: The Issue Is Race; The Cubans

abstract.p: Ivelisse Estrada letter, responding to June 5 article Best of Friends, Worlds Apart, in series How Race Is Lived in America, recalls submerging Puerto Rican heritage in order to assimilate as adolescent child in Texas (M)

block.p: Re ''Best of Friends, Worlds Apart'' (front page, June 5):

Re ''Best of Friends, Worlds Apart'' (front page, June 5):

Born in Puerto Rico, I moved at age 9 to Humble, Tex. I was an instant novelty to my peers -- someone who spoke Spanish but who didn't look Mexican. I worked very hard to erase this difference, to assimilate, and my coloring allowed it. By high school, I had succeeded in turning myself into a virtual Texan.
I did not have a single Latin friend. I had completely denied my heritage. When my parents spoke Spanish in public, I would shush them -- how dare they embarrass me?

Now that I am no longer ashamed of my background, I can't fully reclaim myself. And it is a loss. I mourn the lost stories and the lost traditions. It's fine to belong to a new culture. It's useful. But not at the expense of your identity and self-esteem. I wish I'd understood that in my adolescence.
